entry.title: AWS_Code_Deploy - Setting Up AWS Code Deploy

link.title: AWS_Code_Deploy - Setting Up AWS Code Deploy

entry.content:
AWS Code Deploy

AWS Code Deploy is a CICD pipeline tool that you can use to create a pipeline to AWS EC2 or other AWS computing instances.

Why choose AWS Code Deploy when there are other choices for CICD pipeline?

A pipeline that I used to use was by using Docker, GitHub Actions, and Watchtower. The problem with this is that it uses docker which could consume a lot of memory, leading to failure of a server. However, by using AWS Code Deploy, you can construct a pipeline so that it runs on the operating system such as Ubuntu right on it.

The infra-architecture

The infra-architecture that I will be constructing looks like this.

Step 0️⃣

You need to have an active EC2 instance setup.

Step 1️⃣

Create a S3 bucket using the below options.

Step 2️⃣

Configure S3 IAM user.

Step 2️⃣ - 1️⃣

Create S3 IAM user using the below options.

Step 2️⃣ - 2️⃣

Create an access key and make sure you download the file somewhere safe.

Step 3️⃣

Configure EC2 IAM role.

Step 3️⃣ - 1️⃣

Create IAM role.

Step 3️⃣ - 2️⃣

Modify EC2 IAM role and give the created IAM role to EC2.

Step 4️⃣

Create CodeDeploy IAM role.

Step 5️⃣

Create Code Deploy application and deployment group.

Step 5️⃣

Create Code Deploy application and deployment group.

Step 5️⃣ - 1️⃣

Create application.

Step 5️⃣ - 2️⃣

Create deployment group.

Step 6️⃣

Install and download the following to EC2.

# Download AWS Corretto
$ sudo wget https://corretto.aws/downloads/latest/amazon-corretto-11-x64-linux-jdk.rpm -O java11.rpm

# Install Java 11 JDK
$ sudo apt install openjdk-11-jdk

# Verify Java version
$ java --version

# Install Ruby
$ sudo apt install ruby-full

# Download Seoul region resource kit file for AWS Code Deploy
$ wget https://aws-codedeploy-ap-northeast-2.s3.ap-northeast-2.amazonaws.com/latest/install

# Grant execute
$ chmod +x ./install

# Install agent
$ sudo ./install auto

# Verify agent status
$ sudo service codedeploy-agent status

Step 7️⃣

Add repository secrets to your GitHub repository.

secrets.PROJECT_NAME: Name of your project

secrets.CICD_BUCKET: Name of your cicd bucket

secrets.CODE_DEPLOY_APP_NAME: Name of your CodeDeploy application

secrets.DEPLOYMENT_GROUP_NAME: name of your CodeDeploy deployment group

Step 8️⃣

Create .yaml for GitHub Actions flow to your repository .github/workflows/.

name: CICD using AWS CodeDeploy

on:
  push:
    branches: [ "master" ]

env:
  PROJECT_NAME: $
  BUCKET_NAME: $
  CODE_DEPLOY_APP_NAME: $
  DEPLOYMENT_GROUP_NAME: $

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Setup Java JDK 11
        uses: actions/setup-java@v3
        with:
          distribution: 'adopt'
          java-version: '11'

      - name: Grant execute permission for gradlew and deploy.sh
        run: chmod +x gradlew scripts/deploy.sh
        shell: bash

      - name: Build with Gradle
        run: ./gradlew build
        shell: bash

      - name: Make ZIP File
        run: zip -qq -r ./$GITHUB_SHA.zip .
        shell: bash

      - name: Configure AWS credentials
        uses: aws-actions/configure-aws-credentials@v1
        with:
          aws-access-key-id: $
          aws-secret-access-key: $
          aws-region: $

      - name: Upload to S3
        run: aws s3 cp --region ap-northeast-2 ./$GITHUB_SHA.zip s3://$BUCKET_NAME/$PROJECT_NAME/$GITHUB_SHA.zip

      - name: Code Deploy
        run: aws deploy create-deployment --application-name $CODE_DEPLOY_APP_NAME --deployment-config-name CodeDeployDefault.OneAtATime --deployment-group-name $DEPLOYMENT_GROUP_NAME --s3-location bucket=$BUCKET_NAME,bundleType=zip,key=$PROJECT_NAME/$GITHUB_SHA.zip

Step 9️⃣

Create appspec.yml to your repository’s root path.

version: 0.0
os: linux

files:
  - source: /
    destination: /home/ubuntu/project

permissions:
  - object: /home/ubuntu/project/
    owner: ubuntu
    group: ubuntu

hooks:
  AfterInstall:
    - location: scripts/deploy.sh
      timeout: 60
      runas: ubuntu

Step 1️⃣0️⃣

Create deploy.sh to this path scripts/.

#!/usr/bin/env bash

REPOSITORY=/home/ubuntu/project
APPLICATION_YML=/home/ubuntu/application.yml
cd $REPOSITORY

APP_NAME=project
JAR_NAME=$(ls $REPOSITORY/build/libs/ | grep 'app.jar' | tail -n 1)
JAR_PATH=$REPOSITORY/build/libs/$JAR_NAME

CURRENT_PID=$(pgrep -f $APP_NAME)

if [ -z $CURRENT_PID ]
then
  echo "> $APP_NAME process does not exist"
else
  echo "> kill -9 $CURRENT_PID"
  kill -15 $CURRENT_PID
  sleep 5
fi

echo "> $JAR_PATH Deployed"
nohup java -jar $JAR_PATH --spring.conf.location=$APPLICATION_YML --server.port=8080 > /dev/null 2> /dev/null < /dev/null &

Caution ❗️

Make sure you have your application.yml or application.properties in EC2 if you have any environment variables.

Step 1️⃣1️⃣

Finally, push to GitHub!

entry.title: GitHub Actions - CI Pipeline for Spring Boot

link.title: GitHub Actions - CI Pipeline for Spring Boot

entry.content:
What is GitHub Actions

GitHub Actions allows developers to automate various tasks. For example, we can build CI pipelines for Spring Boot project. In this post, I am going to go through the steps to build CI pipeline for Spring Boot.

1️⃣ Setting in GitHub

First go to your project repository and click on Actions in the menu.

2️⃣ Set up a workflow

If you want to start from scratch, click on set up a workflow yourself ->, otherwise, click on the specific configuration you need.

I am going to set up from the scratch for the example.

3️⃣ Workflow Code

For the sake of the example, I am going to use IntelliJ IDEA. To do this, you just need to add the workflow file. In the root of your project folder, /.github/workflows/develop-ci.yaml. I have named the file develop-ci.yaml because I am going to build a CI(Continuous Integration) pipeline, but you can name it whatever you want. Nevertheless, the file has to be in this specific path: /.github/workflows/

The whole workflow code is going to look like this

name: Develop - CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [ "develop" ]
  pull_request:
    branches: [ "develop" ]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Set up JDK
        uses: actions/setup-java@v3
        with:
          distribution: 'adopt'
          java-version: '11'

      - name: Grant execute permission for Gradlew
        run: chmod +x gradlew

      - name: Build with Gradle
        run: ./gradlew build -x test
        env:
          DB_NAME: ${ { secrets.DB_NAME } }
          DB_PORT: ${ { secrets.DB_PORT } }
          DB_HOST: ${ { secrets.DB_HOST } }
          DB_USERNAME: ${ { secrets.DB_USERNAME } }
          DB_PASSWORD: ${ { secrets.DB_PASSWORD } }

      - name: Build and push Docker image
        uses: mr-smithers-excellent/docker-build-push@v5
        with:
          image: gs97ahn/server
          tags: example-latest
          registry: docker.io
          username: ${ { secrets.DOCKER_USERNAME } }
          password: ${ { secrets.DOCKER_PASSWORD } }

Important ❗️

In the example above, I have spacing between the curly brace. However, it should be not have spacing.

Workflow Code Explanation

This workflow will run everytime a push or pull request is triggered in develop branch. It will do specific tasks given in the ubuntu-latest environment. Theses are the specific steps that it will go through:

  • Set up JDK
  • Grant execute permission for Gradlew
  • Build with Gradle
  • Build and push Docker image

Basically, it will set up jdk and test the code with the test codes that you have. Afterwards, it will build it to your docker repository.

4️⃣ Setting up Secrets

The ${ { secrets } } in the code is the environment variable that you give when you compile and run the program. The reason for being secret is because there are certain variables that you would want it to be secrets like the example below:

  • port number
  • docker repository username
  • docker repository password
  • database username
  • database passwords

Important ❗️

If you do not set up this secrets in your github, you will encounter error because your code will require these secrets everytime the code is compiling.

4️⃣ - 1️⃣

To set up secrets, go to Settings in your project repository.

4️⃣ - 2️⃣

Then click on Secrets in the left menu bar.

4️⃣ - 3️⃣

Then click on New repository secret.

4️⃣ - 4️⃣

Finally name the secret and write the value. Then click Add secret.

5️⃣ Done

Try pushing your work to the branch to see github actions in work.

  • git add .
  • git commit -m "[CHORE] CI pipeline configured"
  • git push

You can find the github actions in work by going to actions menu in your github repository.

Reference

  • TechWorld with Nana in Youtube

entry.title: AWS EC2 - Setting Up AWS EC2

link.title: AWS EC2 - Setting Up AWS EC2

entry.content:
What is AWS EC2

In order to have a backend application. You need to have a server. Not everyone has a server computer in their home😅. This is when you use AWS EC2. EC2 stands for Elastic Compute Cloud. You can borrow a server computer with a specific pricing that AWS provide. Basically, you can understand it as a rental server.

Step 0️⃣

First you need to have an AWS account. So sign up and get free tier for your practice.

Tip ❗

If you are not prepared with your server application. Code First! Because you want to have your free tier as long as possible.

Step 1️⃣

Select the region from the top navigation bar. This region should be closest to your client’s region.

I am currently trying to have a service in South Korea. Therefore, I will be selecting Seoul(ap-northeast-2).

Step 2️⃣

Select launch instance from the EC2 Dashboard.

Step 3️⃣

Name your instance and choose the operating system you would like.

For my specific example, I will be choosing ubuntu 22.04 as it is eligible for free tier.

Step 4️⃣

Select the instance type that you would like. Depending on the computing power that you need, this may vary. Of course, if you choose a powerful instance, you would need to pay more for the usage.

For my specific example, I will be selecting t2.micro which has 1vCPU, 1GiB memory. This instance is eligible for free tier usage.

Step 5️⃣

Set up a key pair. This is not required, however it is important that you need to set this up for security reasons as you do not want anyone else to access your ec2 instance. Click on the “Create new key pair” if you do not have a key pair already.

After clicking on the “Create new key pair”, name your key pair and select the options that you need.

You should probably stick with RSA because ED25519 is not supported for Windows instance in case you are need Windows instance.

For private key file format, depending on your favor, whether it is OpenSSH or PuTTy, select the option.

Finally, click Create key pair and keep the file somewhere secure. If you lose this file, you will not be able to get into your ec2 instance ever again.

For the sake of my example, I am going to select RSA and .pem format.

Step 6️⃣

Next is setting up the network settings. If you have a constant IP address, and you will want to access the EC2 instance only from the specific computer, Click on the Anywhere 0.0.0.0/0 and customize it or select “My IP” which would be your current IP address.

If you are having a backend application in the EC2, you need to allow HTTPs or HTTP or both traffic from the internet. This is your clients accessing your server for requests and responses.

For my example, I am going to run a Spring Boot application, so I am going to allow HTTP traffic only. Also, I am going to allow SSH traffic from Anywhere.

Step 7️⃣

Next step is setting up storage. For free tier, AWS allows you to have upto 30GB, but you probably would like to check on the pricing to reduce surprises that you might encounter in the future.

For my example, I am going to give 10GiB to my storage.

Step 8️⃣

If you want your instance to have GPU or other advanced setting, you can configure it in “Advanced details”.

For my example, I do need any of the advanced settings for now, so I am just going to ignore this part.

Step 9️⃣

Last but not least, you need to select how many instance, meaning how many server computer that you are going run.

I am going to select just one for the sake of this example.

Finally, click on the “Launch instance”, and AWS will prepare you for your EC2 instance. Congrats! 🎉

Step 🔟

You have various ways to connect to your EC2 instance:

  • EC2 Instance Connect
  • Session Manager
  • SSH client
  • EC2 serial console

I usually use EC2 Instance Connect or SSH client as it is my favor of usage.

And of course, as it is default to be “On Demand”, you can stop your server, or get rid of it any time you would like. However, you need to acknowledge that everytime you stop and re-run your instance, the EC2 IP address will change.
